The Perfection of Generosity
The Story of Saṅkha
“Then again, when I was
the brahmin named Saṅkha,
I wanted to cross the great ocean,
so I went to the port.
There I saw on the way🔽the Self-Existent One, the Unconquered One,
traveling through the wilderness,
on a difficult and rough road.
Seeing him on the way,
I thought this:
‘This field has arrived
for a being who desires merit.
Just as a farmer,
seeing a field with great potential,
if he doesn’t sow seeds there,
he won’t have any grain.
In the same way, I who desire merit,
seeing this supreme field,
if I don’t make an offering there,

original: Nāhaṁ puññena atthiko.🔽Yathā amacco muddikāmo,🔽rañño antepure jane;
analyzed: na aham puññena atthikaḥ  yathā amaccaḥ muddi kāmaḥ  raññaḥ antepure jane
translated: I won’t have any merit.🔽Just as a minister who desires wealth,
if he doesn’t give to the people in the king’s inner palace🔽wealth and grain,
he loses his wealth.
In the same way, I who desire merit,
seeing this vast offering,
if I don’t give a gift to him,
I will lose my merit.’
Having thought thus,🔽I took off my sandals,
and after worshipping his feet,

analyzed: adāsim chattupāhana  tena iva aham  sukhu mālaḥ su khedhitaḥ
translated: I gave him my sunshade and sandals.🔽Because of that, I was reborn a hundred times🔽as a god and a human being,
and I was always well-dressed and well-fed.🔽I gave him the sunshade and sandals
because I wanted to complete my generosity.”
The Second Story of Saṅkha is finished.
